awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: The Curriculum Mapping Tool for Sociology: Development, Implementation, Assessment, and Dissemination
awd_abstract_narration:
In an increasingly technological society, the improvement of undergraduate preparedness for STEM fields is of vital interest to the advancement of science, health, prosperity, and national defense.  Evidence indicates that students in many undergraduate STEM programs progress through their majors without sufficient engagement with scientific content, especially with respect to data analysis and rigorous scientific inquiry. Clear learning objectives coupled with meaningful assessment have great promise to address this concern.  The proposed study seeks to refine and disseminate a curriculum development tool and facilitate its use in 150 undergraduate sociology programs.  The tool will assist faculty members in their efforts to evaluate programmatic strengths and weaknesses with respect to seventy objectives contained within twelve overarching recommendations advanced by the American Sociological Association's report "The Sociology Major in the Changing Landscape of Higher Education: Curriculum, Careers, and Online Learning."  The tool will facilitate curriculum review, guide faculty members through the process of curriculum revision, and provide benchmarking data.  The project is designed to help departments understand how they compare to peer institutions.  If successful, the curriculum mapping tool can be modified for use in other STEM fields.  

The study has four distinct goals.  Goal 1 is to develop a curriculum mapping tool for sociology, which draws upon an already tested tool developed by the researchers.  The tool will integrate spreadsheets, videos, and other supplemental components within a survey platform. Goal 2 is to engage 150 sociology departments in curriculum mapping activities, which involves teaching faculty the process of curriculum mapping and gauging their response to insights identified. Goal 3 is to benchmark conformance to recommended curricular standards, which requires analyzing the curriculum maps developed in individual departments. Goal 4 is to assess the impact that curriculum mapping has on program quality, which involves identifying the extent that curriculum mapping produced meaningful changes to course offerings and program structures. Department chairs will be surveyed at three points over the course of three years, providing detailed information on faculty receptivity to curriculum mapping and impacts on program design at their institutions.  Impact of exposure to benchmarking data will be examined with a randomized experimental design.  Curriculum maps generated will document the extent to which departments conform to disciplinary standards.  In addition to publication of results, leading scholars of teaching and learning in other STEM fields will be shown how curriculum mapping operates within sociology programs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Sweet and Ferguson

NSF-IUSE Grant

Outcomes Report

December 2023

 

The Curriculum Mapping Toolkit for Sociology provides as a fully integrated set of resources to help leaders review and refine undergraduate sociology programs. This toolkit is publicly accessible at https://www.ithaca.edu/academics/school-humanities-and-sciences/project-overview-curriculum-mapping-toolkit-sociology. The tool includes guidance and tools to progress through seven discrete steps that instruct departments on ways to identify leaders, determine collective interest, develop mission/vision statements, identify program goals and understand disciplinary recommendations, map curricula, interpret curriculum maps and consider means of moving knowledge to action. The toolkit includes a website, instructional videos, worksheets, a curriculum mapping tool, and is structured to provide a custom report to all departments that complete the CMTS process.

We successfully recruited 117 department representatives, most commonly department chairs to present the CMTS to their colleagues for curriculum review. That represents agreement from one in five (18 percent) department leaders to advocate for our project. Of those who agreed to present the CMTS to colleagues, 55 successfully did so (46 percent). Of those who presented the CMTS to colleagues, 50 secured department commitment to work with the CMTS (91 percent). Of the 50 departments that made commitments to move forward, 35 were able to reach consensus on their mission and vision, as well as discuss the ASA recommendations for the undergraduate major (70 percent); 28 departments completed curriculum mapping (56 percent); and 25 departments assessed their curriculum maps to the point where they were positioned to move forward with action plans (50 percent).

The CMTS advocates that each of the 12 American Sociological Association (ASA) recommendations be seriously considered (but not necessarily followed) when departments decide on program designs. A total of 35 departments discussed the ASA recommendations, involving an estimated 396 individual faculty members. Findings show that for almost every recommendation advanced by the ASA, departments successfully reached strong collective agreement on the merits of that recommendation. The only recommendation that received a temperate response concerned recognizing the convergence and divergence of sociology with other disciplines (Recommendation 8), where only 44 percent of departments reached consensus agreement. Two in three departments reached consensus agreement on the merits of integrating progressive learning structures (69 percent, Recommendation 4) and on the merits of systematic assessment (74 percent, Recommendation 12). All the other recommendations received general collective agreement from 80 percent or more of sociology departments. Note also that very few departments reached consensus disagreement with the merits of any of the recommendations. These findings are also presented in a forthcoming article in the journal Teaching Sociology.

To assess the impact of curriculum mapping on program quality we fielded two follow-up studies (2021 and 2022) to gain perspective on how departments responded to the CMTS, changes made in their sociology programs, and impact on interpersonal dynamics in departments. Those two studies were merged to provide data on 75 departments involved in our study. We asked department representatives (DRs) to report on their experiences in implementing the CMTS. As they began the curriculum review work, two in three (64 percent) DRs reported that their pre-existing curricula had modest concerns (50 percent) or serious concerns (14 percent). Only one in five programs (21 percent) had both mission and vision statements, and only slightly more than one in three programs had curriculum designs that were closely aligned with mission and vision (37 percent). After using the CMTS, two in three departments had both mission and vision statements (68 percent) and nearly two in three departments had curricula that were closely aligned with those statements. These findings present strong evidence that the CMTS proved highly effective at helping sociology departments clarify current and future curricular priorities and reconfigure programs to match those objectives.

From the perspective of the DRs, nearly all departments were very or somewhat successful in reaching agreement on the ASA recommendations (91 percent) and mapping individual courses in accordance with the Sociological Literacy Framework (96 percent). Of those departments that were able to make it to the point of developing action plans based on their work with the CMTS, nearly three in four (70 percent) were successful in doing so. Perhaps most important is that prior to working with the CMTS, only one in four programs (27 percent) had a curriculum that was closely aligned with the ASA recommendations for the undergraduate major. After working with the CMTS, nearly one in two did (44 percent).

Collectively, findings indicate that many sociology programs operate less than optimally, often times lacking clear direction with respect to priorities and objectives. Data indicate that the CMTS helped departments focus on purpose, agree on existing-identified best practices, evaluate programs with respect to those priorities and practices, and adjust programs to create stronger curricular coherence.
